text: Bottle thanks to jsquire: Poured a hazy yellow with a white. Aroma very funky. Taste is tart and funky. Very surprisingly good since I wouldnt have know about them if it wasnt for Jeff.
Bottle from Liquor Barn. Very dry and vinous. Almost too tart, but very enjoyable.

Bottle (2011 vintage drank in 2015): Poured a hue golden yellow color lambic with small bubbly head with limited retention. Aroma of light green apple notes with some tart notes and light vinous undertones. Taste is also dominated by tart green apple notes with some vinous notes, light oak and light funky ester with a thin finish. Body is thinner then I was expecting with OK carbonation. Not bad but doesnt have the depth of the top Belgian lambic producer.
Pours a golden yellow with fizzy head. Aromas of lemony, vinous, barnyard funk. Tastes tart sour apple barnyard funk. This one was a little flat...
Nice lambic bretta with citrus and some cracker. Hazy, tangy, good balance overall. Bottle shared at a tasting a while back.

Bottle share at Toms house. Poured a somewhat cloudy tan-orange with no head. Aroma is light cheese funk, some popping citrus like lemon and orange, hints of vinegar. The taste is fruity up front with citrus and some peach, acedic acid, light yeast funkiness on the backend. Not terribly in depth. But for a domestic lambic not bad.
Bottle pour at Travlrs Mini Bottle Share gathering. Cloudy gold with small white head. Some funky citrus rind, notes of flora and spice. No polish. They should probably try blending this.
From a bottle at the RB DC tasting September 6. Pours a hazy gold with an off white head. Bandaid aroma. Flavors of fermented alfalfa.

Golden colour, white head. Sour aroma, diacetyl, butter, lemon rinds. Sour flavour, butter candy (those old fashioned Dutch yellow butter waffles), fudge, funky notes. Finish butter candy, citrus, lemon zest. Not very complex, and a bit heavy on butter for my liking, but decent and with some balance. Not bad at all.(from 75cl bottle @ Lets drink all of Richs American beers Tasting. Thanks for sharing, omgrich!)

15/VIII/15 - 75cl bottle @ Were drinking all of Richs American beers tasting - BB: n/a, 2013 vintage (2015-1063) Thanks to omgrich for sharing the bottle!
Clear pale blond beer, creamy small aery white head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: bit fruity, spicy, bit dry, funky touch. MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: pretty bitter, lemon rind, some grapefruit, funky touch. Aftertaste: lemon rind, funky, very soft, nice but not very complex. Very curious about how an Ohio brewery exposes their wort to the wild yeast and bacteria (not bacterias) from the Senne Valley. Dumped a bottle of Cantillon and a bottle of 3F in their, I suppose, except I wouldve expected a better outcome then. :p
At Richs Massive Cellar Emptying Tasting. Lambic 2013 a cloudy gold with a tart, bready and mild. The taste is oak, spice, soft bodied. An ok beer but very mild for anything calling itself a lambic.

Bottle @ Drink Richs American beer, thanks to Omgrich. Anno 2013.
Dorée, léger trouble, col blanc se dissipant rapidement.
Arôme au bouquet rappelant un cidre de pomme, le tout sur un funk modéré et pointe de malt.
Palais est sec, léger fruité, pointe de funk avec un léger fruité, le tout gardant cette impression de cidre sec. Je peine à y trouver le lien avec un lambic. Reste assez monodimensionnelle.

This was a 2011 bottle sampled in June of 2015. Its slightly cloudy orange w/ a head of fine bubbles. It is slightly grainy--corn specifically--w/ subdued tartness for the style. I am not getting much funk or phenolics just straight acidity. Its lightly sweet, medium bodied w/ mild carbonation. There is some flight fruit character and maybe just a touch of bitterness in the finish. I dont know that this resembles a lambic much at all but it is an OK beer at least.

growler to glass. this was leftovers from fest of ales and still good in the growler. pours a muddy yellow color with no head with mild carbonation. aroma is a beautiful cluster of funk, brett, barnyard, wet horse blanket, acid, lemon and or other citrus. flavor is that and more. very nice tart right off the back followed by all of the funk, brett, barnyard, citrus and lemon bright and everescent. solid flavor. if you arent a fan of sour/tart beers leave this one alone its awesome.

Pours a hazy golden color with a slightly fluffy white head. Aroma of lemon zest, light cheese, and barnyard funk. Taste is of lemon, mild cheese, mouth puckering tartness, slight malts, funk, slight vinegar. Overall, a solid beer. Would recommend to others.

Bottle. Cloudy orange pour with a 1 finger head that fades slowly to a thin film and a thick collar. Aroma is pack with sour lemons and limes, some white grape, light barnyard funk, and oak. Tastes very sour. Loads of vinegar and lemon/lime, some cheese and brett funk, grape and apple in the finish. Medium body. Love this.

Poured into a tulip. 2012 vintage. Like the Rivertown Gueuze I had a little while ago, the cap came off of this way, way, way too easily. While this beer may have been flat anyway, the gueuze should not have been.

3.5 A: Mildly hazed orange brown color. No head.

3.5 S: The nose on this is sharp and acidic. Loads of lactic acid with plenty of acetic underneath. Tangy and fruity with peach and apple. Melon and some vinous notes underneath. Hay and dry woody funkiness, but it doesnt hold a candle up to the acid. Oak without much tannic astringency.

1.75 T: Wow. On the pucker-scale, this one shoots right past mouth-puckering and straight to ass-puckering. Most of the time, the first sip makes a sour beer seem more sour than it is. Your palate needs a couple sips to acclimate back to sours. This beer does not apply. Its fully unbalanced with bracing acidity and unrelenting intensity. I can feel my tooth enamel dripping down my esophagus. If you can taste anything past the acid, you might say this beer is tangy and fruity. Again apple, peach, and vinous fruitiness. Hay and oaky woodiness. Its so damn sour that I cant keep it in my mouth long enough to discern any other flavors.

3.5 M: Lighter medium body. Not really any carbonation. Drinks like a thick water, which is a nice mouthfeel for a lambic.

1.5 D: If Im dead tomorrow then its probably because I finished the bottle by myself. Wholly undrinkable, even for the most seasoned lambic drinkers. Im not a sour noob, so Im not overreacting. This may be even less balanced that the Cantillon Kriek I had a while back. Brace yourselves, acid is coming.

Pour out of 22 oz bottle, slightly hazy golden pour with white head, aroma brought notes of cracker, bread into a bit of yeast, hints of tart lemon, slight oak, touch of funky earth. Taste was a mix of earth, funk, grass into some lemon, lacto notes with a touch of bready, doughy notes, finishing fairly tart. Pretty tasty, but not very complex.

(bottle - 22 oz - 2011 vintage) Clear copper pour with not much in the way of a head. Tart as hell in the nose with a lot of dry fruits and grassy notes. Flavor is tart and sour as well. Some mild cider notes with a dry sour finish.

Bottle at home with my wife. Pour is clear orange with a big white head and decent lacing. Funky, lemony, somewhat cheesy, lemon peels, light grass, sweet tarts, and oaky aroma. Taste is lemony, urine, some cheese, grass, biscuit, some wood tones, citrus peels with a medium sour finish. Medium body with carbonation. Would love a little more funk, but damn tasty nonetheless.

Funky sweet aroma. Pale golden in color with no head. Not very tart; watery and light in body with a light brett aroma.

Notes: GABF 13

Pours hazy apricot with a thin eggshell head. Sour aroma is all fruit, all the time. Boldly sour flavor will make your face do aerobics! Pomme and citrus fruit, hint of sweetish malt. Texture is quite fizzy and rather firm. Go wild!

Shared at Ale Alpharetta. Nice, hazy, gold, with a thin grey ring. Lemon zest, hay, white sugar, mango, and cloves. Sweet and venous, with a great, mellow, tart character. Medium body, crisp, and clean. Overall, this is excellent. Great balance, and a fantastic flavor and body.

Bottle shared at the End of History tasting. Aroma of lemon juice, buttery oak, and some perfume funk. Pours blond and hazy with a small wispy white head. Taste is oaked chardonay, butter, oak, lemon, and a cheesy funky finish. Nice balance of tart and funky and the oak presence is definitely an interesting presence. Makes me want to try the Gueuze again.

750 ml bottle thanks to Willrunforbeer for sharing this 2013 vintage. Dirty hazy gold color. Aroma is dirty socks, horse blanket, moldy oak and a trace of vinaigrette. 
Flavor shows lactic sourness, old oak, dirty jock strap and straw. Tart and sour, it is what it should be. Chewy body with a very dry texture. Thanks for sharing Brian.

750 mL bottle supplied by WillRunForBeer - many thanks! To long-stemmed white wine glass, it pours a partially-hazy deep orange with which a white-ringed head half a finger in length stood, Aromas od Cortland apples, denim jeans, bosc pears, farmhouse yeast, and blueberry leaves. Tastes the same with the addition of plastic, lime meat, soy beans, and white wine lees. Soft and palateable.
Bottle shared at Radarsocks. Pours golden peach with a scant orange white head. Aroma is lime, barnyard funk, grape skins. Taste is tart, lime, orange. Grapeskin and lime bitter in the finish.

2011
Nice golden peach color 1 finger head. Slight vinegar nose. Taste is peach, lime and kiwi with a brett like doughy taste.

With Z, pours an amber orange color with no head. Nose is fruity, with a nice funky sourness and tartness. Taste is ripe fruit with deep tartness and mouth puckering sourness, dry and delicious, with a cider like tannin finish. A real nice lambic ! Quaff Score 8 / 10

Bomber. Pours an amber orange with a dissipating beige head and tart, sour, fruity aroma. Taste is tart and sour up front, fruity and wine flavors throughout along with some funk leading to a dry, tart finish. Nice lambic

Bottle at End of History tasting. You know its far along in a tasting when i look at notes in phone and my review has a lot of cursing and spelling mistakes but I was able to translate and edit for television. orange pour and nose of brett and citrus. tastes amazing of the unblended thing i cant put my finger on. you get florals, apricot, lime, and yeast. tart and refreshing. this is a great effort.
2011 bottle, thanks to drfabulous. Pale clear orangish pour. Aroma of barnyard, oak, acetone; rubber, cereal and light vinegar; some bubblegum as well. Light body and refreshing.
Bottle. Orange pour with white head. Light tart fruit, citrus, funky aromas. Flavors are not as nice sour tones.

Where and how:  Tasting, Bottle 750 ml , 2012 Vintage
Aroma cinnamon, red apple, vanilla, cherry, gooseberry and red beries. Sweet on top , tad too sweet. 
 Appearance : 
Top: bright white top.
Base: hazy golden with touches of amber, fine texture.
Palate : lip smacking tartness, milder carbonation. 
Taste: peach , red apple. Interesting. 
 other notes  nothing exceptional but nicely made.

Poured from a bottle. Holy gusher!!!!! After 1 minute of it spewing all over the place. Murky to the point that it looks like ice coffee, with a small head. Very nice aroma consisting of chocolate, fruit and wine. Medium body with a strange sour fruit flavor and a mild cardboard finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Earthy aroma, with traces of wine, malt and fruit. Turbid cafe au lait colour with a fair amount of sediment. Mild taste, slightly tart, with undertones of Chardonnay, and tart apples. Creamy feel with a tart finish.

Bottle... Pours hazy and golden with no head. The bouquet offers a nice level of acidity, fruitiness and funk - lemon peel, leather and cherry SweeTart with a whisper of vanilla. Medium-bodied and watery with trace carbonation. The flavor and finish are watery and thin with a light tanginess. Enjoyable and refreshing, although unspectacular. Bottle shared by biggsbowler!

Rating #2500: bottle (2013) from Savor Growl. Gold pour with thin white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma of funky brett, cider, dusty. Tastes are on the sweet side with lemon, green apple, zesty, little oak, grape, slight vinegar. Light to moderate sourness. Texture is slick thin to medium with just a tingle of carbonation late. Little dry in the finish.
Hazy yellow pour, small head. Oak, citrusy, funky aroma. Dry mouthfeel. Citrus, sour, oak, white wine, grape, barnyard. Easy drinking. Much thanks bob!
Smoothly drinkable lambic. Cherry and oak aroma. Cloudy fruity orange colour. Big mouthfeel. Dry finish. Good drinkability.

Bottle thanks to RJ5020, 2011 vintage - thanks! Pours hazy butterscotch, small white head, fizzy and disispates quickly leaving some lacing. Aroma is funky, basement must, horse blanket, very oaky, light lemon. Flavor is light plus tart, oaky, lightly funky - less than the nose would have indicated, a bit of fruitiness, perhaps white grape. Light body, sharp carbonation. Some lingering acidity. This is a pretty nice beer.
Mildly hazy light orange. Citrusy orange fruit and very tart sour aroma. Very sour, juicy yum flavor as well. More sour and tart the finish.
Bottle thanks to dextercat. Aroma of sour and more sour. Taste is more sour. Lips and jowls puckering... More sour.
Nice and sour. Great and tart on the palette. Definitely cant drink a bottle by yourself.

2011-bomber. Dark gold pour with small head. Nose of musty fruit, lacto, and citrus. Taste follows the nose with some vinous qualities.  Dry sour finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle pours a slightly hazy golden/orange with a small white head. Aroma is sweet apricot and lemon with some funky musk. Pretty mild flavors, citrus and some wine barrel presence, slight funk and sourness. Enjoyable, but almost a little watered down compared to Belgium lambics, still enjoyed it!

22 oz. bottle, pours a hazy golden orange with a small beige head. Aroma brings out wine barrels, oak, and Belgian yeast. Flavour is more like a saison, with a very feint lambic quality, some Belgian yeast, and light funk. I get what theyre trying to do, but it really isnt a traditional lambic at all. Pretty damn awesome though for what it is. Delicious beer, despite it not being a typical lambic. Great stuff.

Bottle (2012 vintage) pours hazy amber with tiny head. Nose is musty sour white grape, funk, oak, lemon. Taste is acidic sour lemon-lime citrus, grape skin, wet barrel, moderate funk. Finish is sour acidic citrus, touches of subtle earthy grain, nice barrel notes, juicy golden delicious apple, lacto. Nice.

Excellent blonde sour, strange shape bottle from an ohio State fan of mine. Creamy head, I like the carbonation even tho they are supposed to be a tad under carbonated. Ciders vinegar and predominatly green apple sour. A dry chalky finish, real easy to get used to this one!
Really really good. This has a very nice dry finish. Tempered tartness and a lightly sweet beginning. Favor is apples, pears, floral, funk, and just tasty. Loved it.
wow this is was surprise, fantastic. This also isnt a lambic, its a golden sour. Sour and barrel aged , balanced, great stuff.

Wow this was surprisingly easy to drink. Great carbonation level. Ive been frustrated by flat sours lately. Tart, sour, and clean. This was just fun. Green and yellow sweet and sour fruits. Some herbal and vegetal notes that are nicely in balance. Maybe it was a touch simple, but if it was then it was simply good.

Bottle courtesy of Secret Santa (summer 2013). Thank you jsquire! Pours hazy golden with a frothy orangish white head that quickly dissipates while leaving a small trace on the glass. Smell is sour and slightly phenolic with crackers, lemon juice, hay, rubber, horse blanket, grapefruit juice, lemon zest, green apples, dry wood, hay and hints of barnyard. Taste is sour, tiny metallic and slightly phenolic with crackers, lemon juice, unripe apples, unripe pears, hay, dry soil, grapefruit juice, lemon zest, gastric acid, rubber, barnyard and dry wood. Mouthfeel is dry, tart and light bodied. Finish is sour and slightly phenolic with crackers, lemon juice, grapefruit juice, hay, dry soil, barnyard, horseblanket, lemon zest and hints of gastric acid. A nice surprise. Impressively authentic and nicely refreshing.

Bottle, thanks to Alex. Somewhat hazy golden/yellow beer, almost no head. Sourish rubber aroma, tart, floral, raisins, grapefruit, sour, vinegar, apples, some dandelions. Sourish flavor, grapefruit, citrus, hay, tart, floral, dandelions, sour, tart, vinegar notes. Hay and dandelions in the finish.

Bottle shared in thebaldmuffs room post grand tasting at rbwg this year. This was a little disappointing and overly watery for me after all I had heard about it all of these years. Still, a valiant effort at a very difficult style to perfect or even just make drinkable.
Bottle generously shared during the post-grand tasting muff party at RBWG. Low on the lactic acidity. Slightly watery body. Some some pineapple tartness. Ok overall.
Bottle at the Dick Cheese tasting. Light amber pour. Muffs. Lots of lemon. Tasty but a bit one dimensional.
Bottle as shown. Pours a hazey gold with no head. The aroma is pear, oak, and yeast. Thin mouthfeel with strong pear juice and oak with lingering dry finish. Odd

750. Thanks, D! Pours a cloudy medium yellow with a loose and fizzy white head. Sharp lemony notes on the nose, with some white vinegar also present. Creamy medium body with very lively carb. Bright lemon and white vinegar qualities on the mid palate, with a bit of mineral near the finish. Quite nice.

2012 bottle from PhallusU. Pours nice and gold with a persistent, thick white head. Aroma is super tart and fruity. Citrus, sour, tart apple. Taste is tart apple, puckering, sweet, but nice and crispy. Definitely true to description, very much like a tart cider. Very enjoyable. 

p.s. fuck you, eat shit
DLD 2013 Bottle Share. Clear copper with no head. Aroma of honey, sweet citrus, and musty oak. Flavor is of grape, pear, yeast, leather, and barnyard. Tart and dry finish.

bottle from someone I traded with, forgot who @ this point. Thanks though! Pours a hazed tangerine color with only the slightest of heads. Aromas of some mild tart fruit, perhaps a bit of must. Taste is like a dry flat cider from spain, which would be a good thing in a cider but not here. Apple is detected, which was not intended. Little to no carb. Little to no funk. Mildly tart. No real brett presence. This is pretty entry level stuff and to be honest, kind of bush league.

@ Jungle Jims / Eastgate OH - Slight haze in a dirty gold, heavy white head cover, stripes of lace. Taste is sour, yeasty, earthy malt with a smooth effervescent delivery that makes it fantastic with food (a chef salad tonight). The taste cleans and awakens the palate beautifully, and allows some of the sweet to remain at the finish. A superb example of the style.

Bottle. Hazy golden liquid with small to medium white head. Aroma of lemon, sugar, barnyard, apples, vanilla, wood and bread. Taste is dry and light to medium sour with notes of lemon, barnyard and vanilla. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Ok.
Orange haze, minimal head. Funky, barnyard-esque aroma. Grassy, yeasty, hearty sourness, improves as it warms. Quite nice, should age well.

A - pours hazy golden amber with very little white head. S - honey, sweet tart citrus juice, musty wet oak. Funky, musty and sour. Vinegar and acidic. M - light and drinkable. Nice citrusy tartness and sweetness go hand in hand. A nice balance. Musty funky sweet tart and tasty. T - lemon and lime juice lead the way. Musty wet oak, honey and honeysuckle, and simple sugar in the palate. Mineral water, metallic notes and lemon juice to end. O - I'm no lambic expert but this is just a good sour. Nice. 3.9

Pours a clear light copper with no head. Aroma is tart and "minty" (not sure what I meant by that). Taste is indeed tart but also fruity/cidery. Alas it isnt too complex. Body is lean, mouthfeel vinous. Strangely the carbonation is high, not something I would have expected from a lambic (versus a geuze). Nice but not outstanding.

2011 vintage. pours hazy light golden with a small white cap, some retention and lacing. soft brettiness, floral-grassiness, pepper, nice fruitiness - white grapes and pears, yeasty - bit dusty and leathery, acidity under control - relatively complex. moderate carbonation - slightly lacking, light body - oily, dry bretty, lightly acidic and herbal finish. although it is not worldclass, it is very nice and enjoyable.
(2011 vintage): Très cuiré et sauvage, des petits fruits se manifestent également. En bouche cest typique lambic avec une touche vanillée qui fait le pont vers la sécheresse. Buvabilité sauvage.

750 ml bottle poured a clear gold with a lingering ring of white foam. Aromas of straw, lemon and light barnyard funk. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry tart finish. Flavors of straw, barnyard funk and citrus with a crisp dry tart finish.

Bottle (750 ml). 2011 vintage. From Scott, thanks! Clear golden/straw color with no head and no lacing. Aroma is of leather, barnyard and light fruits. Taste is about the same with the fruits being a little more present and a touch of vanilla and spices. Light to medium body. Low to moderate carbonation. Slightly vinous and dry. Good complexity. Interesting.
Golden pour, small white head. Aroma is very funky, tart smelling, very nice. Taste is sweet and tart, not quite sour, slightly dry, funky. Not bad.

Bottle. Pours a hazy yellow golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity sour tart weak funky woody aroma. Fruity malty sour tart funky flavor. Has a fruity malty sour tart weak funky citrus finish.
Pours a hazy yellow gold from the shared bottle, no real head or lacing. Aroma of funky lactic sourness, slight grain. Taste follows, a hint of sweetness that covers the extreme sour. Very nice!

Sampled at GABF 2013. Golden pilsner-esque pour. Strong sour nose. The taste is an assault of pomegranate, lemon, and apple cider. Sourness lingers on the palate. An awesome beer and one of the best beers I sampled at GABF 2013.

GABF 2013 
Aroma is dusty malts and mild tartness. Flavors are dusty and grainy, dry finish 
Decent, mild and clean
Sampled at GABF 2013. Yellow/gold appearance with a white head. Tart and fruity aroma with wild yeast, bacteria, wine and cider. Lightly sour and sweet with a dry finish.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2013 Shared by NobleSquirrel, 750ml bottle poured into a small La Chouffe glass. Headless dull golden pour, cant see throught it. Aroma is a medium acetic with lemon and sweet sour. Flavor has some vinegar with a nail polish twist. Fruity vinegar American sour but not too bad or over the top, just some rough edges.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Via trade with Bmart. The aroma is wild, funk, sour lemon, sour grape. The appearance is an opaque gold/orange, thin white head, lots of carbonation bubbles. The flavor is acidic lemon, barnyard, dry red wine. The finish is sour, citrus, lingering. Medium in body, a bit creamy on the mouthfeel. Pretty nice. Nicely executed representation for this ununual style. Glad I got to try this.

A: Golden Straw Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring, Some Lacing

S: Hay, Apricots

T: Apricots, Hay, Mild Bitter Peach

M: Average Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Bitter

Overall, A nice mildly bitter lambic with a nice balanced flavor.
Bottle at Amager Bryghus - Tasting - thanks to Papsø. Clear golden - offwhite head. Acid, wooden, gooseberries, light sourness, bretty, peppery, simple, ok crispy, leather, barnyard. OK.
Bottle. Clear yellow pour with white head. Sour aromas. Mildly tart with mild citrus notes. Not very complex. Below average mouthfeel and body.

Bottle. Hazy gold pour, white head. Little retention/lace. Aroma of barrel, funk, apricot, white wine. Taste is dry, tart, light dust, whine wine, apricot, moderately lactic. Palate is average carbonation, slick, tart finish.

Bottled. Golden coloured. Unclear. Dense light beige head. Aroma. Sourness, leather, light horseblanket, brett and grape. Flavour. Sourness, citrus, brett, leather, vague barnyard. Medium to full bodied. Ends dry and sour with a light citric touch.

750 ml bottle. Pours reddish golden, little head. Nice sour aroma, big sour attack! Slight carbonation, nicely built in to lighten the sourness. Oak comes through towards the end with a nice lingering sour close. Nice beer, could use a little less sourness or more flavor to balance.

Sample from 75 cl. bottle, 2011 Vintage. Slightly hazy, deeper golden colour with a small, white head. Tart aroma with yeasts, fruits, green grapes and oak. Taste is sour. Medium body with an average carbonation. Finishes tart and dry with a hint of citrus. Nice US-Lambic.
Bottle - Amber/golden pour with a small white head. Orchard fruits, floral notes, some grass, hay, wood, very tart lemon, sherbet, creamy mouth feel.

Bottle at Tasting at Amager Bryghus. 
Clear golden coloured with a small white head.
Fruity and light acidic aroma with notes of oak.
Fruity flavour of oak with acidic notes.
Tart finish.

Bottle. Light hazy yellow with a white head. Light sour, yellow apples, a little barnyard, light citrus. Light/medium body, good texture and carbonation, but not much complexity. Quite pleasant drink, though.

Bottle 75 cl. Pours an almost clear golden with a smallish white head. Tart, Bretty nose. Medium body, dry and fruity with a salty touch. A little baking yeast. Tart and dry. Not as complex as the belgian examples - naturally - but quite decent. 130913

Bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a medium white head. The aroma is acid, barnyard, wood, leather and brett. The flavor is acid, brett, citrus and wood. Not as sour as the original lambics but a nice attempt. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared at Collected Works tasting. Nice authentic lambic aroma. Pretty lactic and horsey and lemony, bordering on gueuze in terms of the nose. Flavor has some pervasive grape juice sweetness, like Welchs. Solid acidity but the grapiness is too forward.

8/25/13. 750mL bottle thanks to BlackIPA! Hazy golden orange pour, mostly on the orange side, with a small khaki head that sticks and laces pretty darn well. The aroma is lighter than expected but I still dig it. Subtle creamy vanilla intertwines with oak, tropical fruits, a touch of funky wild yeasts, and small hints of citrus acidity. Light flavor as well, mild funkiness with vanilla and oak, a hint of doughy caramel, a touch sweet, a bit of tart acidity and a hint of a metallic aspect. Not bad. Lighter than one would hope, a touch sweet, but tasty and refreshing.

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, 2011 vintage. Pours lightly hazy bright golden straw color with a 2 finger fairly dense white head with good retention, that reduces to a thin lace that lingers. Minimal spotty lacing clings on the glass. Aromas of big tart apple, lemon, pear, grape, clove, oak, hay, grass, vinegar, white wine, funk, leather, and yeast earthiness. Awesome aromas with great balance and complexity of yeast and oak barrel notes; with good strength. Taste of tart apple, lemon, pear, grape, clove, oak, hay, grass, pepper, white vinegar, funk, white wine, leather, and yeast earthiness. Fair amount of acidic tartness on the finish; with lingering notes of light fruits, clove, oak, hay, vinegar, grass, white wine, leather, funk, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice complexity and balance of fruity/spicy/funky yeast flavors with moderate barrel presence; with a great malt/tartness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a smooth, crisp, and moderately acidic mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming noticed after the finish. Overall this is a highly excellent Lambic style! All around great balance and complexity of yeast and barrel flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink with the moderate acidity. A highly enjoyable offering.

Light cloudy gold color with little to no head or lacing. Aroma is vinous, citric and floral. Flavor is great- not overpoweringly sour, but has nice tart apples and grapes, with a mellow creamy oakyness at the end. Very low carbonation with a oily, waxy mouthfeel. Pretty good overall

Bottle via trade, shared at the "Ken says its not sour enough" tasting! It pours hazy gold with a quickly dissipating white head. The nose is mellow, hay, floral, wood, faint must and soft fruit. The taste is lightly tart lemon, earth, hay, floral, sherbet, tart apricot/peach, pomello and mild acidity with a dry, clean finish. Light-medium body, fine carbonation and velvety mouth-feel. Smooth, well balanced and rather drinkable stuff!

750 ml. 2012 vintage. Cloudy golden pear color with a small spit of cream on top. Aroma of tart cherry, caramel, and light hints of oak and vinegar. Tastes the same, plus some old apple peel, grape must, and a touch of bubblegum and wheat. Light-medium body is balanced and has low carbonation. Overall a good American take on the venerable style.

26th June 2013Craft Clerkenwell Tasting. Thanks to Paul. Hazy gold beer, little off white head. Very light and semi dry palate. Super light sourness. Touch of dried fruits. Dry finish. Fine but (and I can barely believe Im saying this) could be more sour!

Refrigerated 75 cl 2001 vintage brown bottle poured into a tulip. Pours slightly hazy yellow with medium white head. Little lacing, medium body, little carbonation, and nice tart aroma. Taste is nice tart, some oak, and some fruit. I like this even better than their blackberry lambic.

Bottle split at Craft Clerko, big thanks to Paul, 26/06/13.
Hazed yellow blonde with no head.
Nose is sour apples, tarte fruits, lemon rind, woody notes, musty, tangy orchard fruit and light smoke.
Taste comprises bitter lemon scrapings, funk, grass, musty fence postm apple skins, tarte white grapes.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, tarte fruit finish.
Solid enough affair.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle thanks to Paul. The pours gold with a small head. The nose is golden syrup, some buttered brioche. White grape. Hints of brett, dried cheese. Some lemon. The taste is more mild brett. Some lemon and cantaloupe smoothie. Only moderately tart. Light body, fine carbonation. Overall, very easy drinking. Nice.

Bottle via 2013 Summer Secret Santa. This bottle leaked just a little (probably just an oz or two) during shipping and made only the slightest hiss of CO2 when I took the cap off. Low carbonation, as expected. Hazy orange pour. Great nose, grapes, melon and citrus. Taste is nice as well. Not overly sour - Judy enough to keep things interesting - fruity, citrusy, slightly funky.

Vintage 2012. Ive never had a lambic, and likely never will again. The taste is sour tart, with a slight sweetness hint. Really its overpowering citris/acid flavor. Its not easy to drink, nor is it hard to drink, just gotta take small sips with breaks in between. I would assume that this is a good lambic, because its not terrible, but its not for me.

Bottle shared at CBC Clerkenwell - many thanks to Paul. Pours lightly hazy yellow with a creamy, white foam head. Nose holds dry dough, light yeast, lemon, mellow funk. Light sweet flavor with moldy lemon, dried pale malts, citrus rind, restrained funky tang. Light bodied with fine, massaging carbonation. Moderately dry on the finish with light tang, some hay, leather. Decent.
Slightly reddish pour into tulip with pink white head.  Aromas of tart bramble fruit.  Taste is light Raspberry and cherry with a tart dry aftertaste.  Really refreshing and crisp in flavor.

2012 vintage in a 1 pint 9.4 oz bottle. Pours a cloudy pale bronze with a rapid fading foam. Starts slightly sweet with a  quick change to slightly sour. I appreciate the difference in a lambic and I so wanted to like this but it's just not for me. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy
Solid american sour ale. Nice funk, it is a bit sweet, but it is also light and effervescent at times.

Bottle. Light golden body. Fizzy white head. Aroma of overripe/slightly rotting fruit, barnyard, apple, lacquer, brett. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter and lightly to moderately acidic. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet, lightly bitter and moderately acidic. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Sour apple, grape taste along with notes of brett, horse blanket.

750ml bottle, 2010 vintage. Been holding onto this one for a year or two. When I removed the wrapping from the top, I was surprised to find how saturated the cork was. Actually, it was the wettest cork ever. Broke in half as I pulled it out, and not in a dry way. Really wet and squishy, so strange. When I finally got the second half of the cork out, it made a loud pop, and gushed a bit. Head eventually fades to nothing, though. Medium-plus body, lighter, soft carbonation, more dry texture. Aroma is kind of just like wet laundry, or wet socks. Flavor is a lot better than the aroma, though. Oaky, tart, woody aroma. Kind of musty, but not in a bad way. Actually, the smell gets a lot more tolerable after it sits for a bit, and I take a few sips, getting used to it. Ive never had a beer from the unblended lambic style before, so Ive got no reference to compare this to... It seems like something might be off here (especially considering the state of the cork), but I cant say for sure. I actually ended up drinking the whole bottle almost entirely on my own without really a problem, though. Its really intriguing, and the more I got used to it, the more I didnt mind it.
Poured a hazy, pale copper with a thin white head of foam. The Aroma is all sour and yeasty. Fruity and sour in the taste with a lighter mouthfeel.  Really nice stuff.

Thanks to Jason for sharing! Pours cloudy dull honey color with slight tan ring. Smell is tart fruit, mild vinegar, citrus. Taste is tart fruit, citrus, vinegar and a bit of artificial sweetener. Light body with a hint of effervescence. Overall interesting but not great.

Style 71 of 72.  Hazy organic honey color with a small quickly diminishing white head.  Aroma of old orange peels, funky yeast and a sense of the old world. Taste as with most lambics is a trait that comes after aroma and mouthfeel, specifically tartness.  Yes there is flavor, a mild citrus and bread, but the initial tartness shocks the taste buds and the dry finish completes the process.  This is a good beer and I appreciate the work and effort that went into it, especially the style,  I just think this is an elementary lambic and it needs to up the umph in regards to funk and tartness.

Thx! to Jason for this one. 2011 Vintage. 75 cl, bottle split @ t Antwaerps Bierhuiske. Apparently made with bacteria from the Senne valley and aged in wine barrels. Bottle is whisky-style with wine bottle decorations. Pours a murky golden with only some brief white bubbles, much murkier than any Belgian counterpart. Smell is nice horseblanket, def. Belgian-style, feel familiar, quite a bit of lemon sourness, light vinegar and lactic touches, some malts, Tate is sour lemon, tart, BE lighter horseblanket, somewhat overpowered by the lemon and lactic sourness, light yoghurt sourness, taste is a touch watery, light vinegar, malts are there, light white wine and oak, I think this is comparable to the BE stuff, def. some lactic touches which you wont find here. Body is much fuller than any of the local examples, some malt substance, Probably dealt with some infections. The owner didnt like it all that much but I did. Thx.

Had this on tap at the East Nashville Beer Festival.  The folks at the Rivertown boot has been telling festival goers that this would be opened at 2pm. By 2pm there was a massive crowd in front of the booth - Im happy that many Nashville beer fans appreciate lambic. Rivertown impressed me again with a well-done lambic. This poured with a huge head, even on the tiny sample I received. Aroma is lightly sour and contains a nice dose of funky fruit. Flavors are a little peppery and dry. Really nice stuff.

A - Hazy golden-orange with a finger of frothy white head. Fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some lacing.

S - Sweet wheat, tart green fruits, oak, wine, vanilla, lemon zest, funky Brett, lactic acid, pepper.

T - Very tart green fruits, sweet wheat, lemon zest, oak, wine, funky Brett, mild pepper and vanilla, lactic acid.

M - Medium bodied, moderate carbonation. Smooth with a tart and dry finish.

D - Very nice lambic. Great overall balance and complexity.

Bottle, 03/14/2013. Pours light golden caramel, one-finger fine white head, fades to some interesting patterns on ths surface, tight-bubbled lacing. Aroma is cidery, with white grape, apples and pears, bit of lemonaid lemon sweetness, yet considerable barnyard, leather, oak. Taste is tart citrus, white grapes and apples, lactic funk and yogurt, oak. Medium body. Very passable for the style, cut down on the sweetness and this could be pretty awesome- not too bad.

There is a nice fruit and yeast scent. The carbonation adds a crisp feel on the tongue. The aftertaste is acidic and fades nicely. The acidic taste weakens the other flavors which is a disappointment. This brew is very kind on the palate. Overall there was not a lot of unique flavors. I did enjoy this Lambic but I would not purchase this again.

Bottle, 2011 vintage, thanks to fatknitty.  Opaque golden beer with a medium white head.  Aroma is very fruity, champagne-like, slightly sour/acidic.  Taste starts out quite nice, perfectly sour and acidic, but it quickly disappears. Finish is pretty much non-existent, some very light acidity, reminds me of seltzer water.  Light body, soft-moderate carbonation.  I would drink it again, particularly on a hot day, but its a disappointment for me.

Bottle, pours a nice bright yellow, nice carbination, nice aroma of a sweet funk and a the body is just right a bit light. The flavour is a nice funk and tastes like a lambic. I was quite impressed with this american offering of this style

Pours hazy gold-yellow with a white, bubbly but very short-lasting head. Aroma is acidic, citrus, sour, funk, vinous. Taste is acidic, vinegar, sour apple, wine-like, some wood notes. Extremely tart aftertaste. High carbonation, which is successful here. Also pretty dry. Light-bodied but full flavored. I really liked this. Very lively and tasty. Aggressive but not overpowering. Hard to find but very happy to have had.

2010 Beautiful beer! sample pour of hazed golden liquid, slight white head that dissipates quickly.  Nose is great citrus, citric, light sour tartness, but really amazing.  Light funky barnyard notes with a little grassiness.  Flavor is amazing.  Really quenching for a lambic, with beautiful citrus almost like a Berliner.  Very smooth, not overly sour, and very drinkable. I could drink this one for awhile.

Pours darkened gold with a short, soapy white head.
Aroma of slightly vinegared white wine.
Taste is a little musty, almost wood aged notes...
Moderately tart...lemony.
Very smooth.

2011 bottle. Tart lactic lemon, musty funky, woody aroma.  Hazy gold with a small white head. Tart lactic lemon,  funky musty, woody flavor smoothed out with a hint of sweetness.  The lactic element seems to transition more towards acetic as it warms.  Light, slightly watery body, lively carbonation, dry finish,

Bottle.  Vinegar, white grape, and apple aroma.  Hazy golden yellow with minimal head.  Sweet-tart white grape, lemon, and vinegar flavor.  Very smooth.  Not nearly as sour as its Belgian counterparts but pretty nice.

Bottle at my 30th Birthday Tasting. Thanks Adam! Pours hazy deep orange, thin white head, no lacing. Nose is white pepper, persimmon, sweat, petroleum. Flavours of clean barley, salt, sweat, lots of lemon goin on here, but really not much else. I know Adam RAVED about this one, but I just dont see it.

What an interesting brew. Thanks, Paul, for sharing. The aroma is full of tart lemon and funky barnyard musk. Basement aromas. Taste is similar with tart and roasted citrus with a funky must that cant be denied. Very true to the style.

Mr. Unwin talked about this one nicely, and for good reason. The color was a cloudy yellow with a nice, thin white head. Lots of sour aromas with grapefruit, lemongrass and fall leaves. The taste was nice and sour as well, like biting into a lemon almost. It was clean and crisp, vinous (yeeaaaah) too with a lingering bitterness. Lemon-y flavors get more sweeter as it warms up, and makes this one solid brew.

Bottle shared by djmiller92. Thanks Dave.

The beer is really hazy and yellow hued, with a thin, white head. The aroma is really nice, with an authentic Belgian lambic vibe. Funky citrus, yeast, hay, straw. The flavor is quite enjoyable, though it lacks the complexity that was potential in the aroma. The finish is not as full or exciting as the first half of the flavor profile. A decent example of an American gueuze.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-03-2011

Bottle @ Darkness Day 2012 shared with buds and some random hippies. Pours a cloudy yellow appearance with a white head. Fairly funky, tart lemon, a bit dusty, barnyard aroma. Actually, pretty complex, dusty, a bit acetic, white wine, lemon, vanilla, moderately sour flavor. Pretty tasty stuff.

One of the benefits of being military and guys go home on leave they bring you beer  . It poured a hazey straw yellow color with a minimal head. The aroma was of tartness, musty and an earthy tone. The flavor was the same as the aroma with a somewhat sour finish.  This was the last style I needed

Bottle from Party Town. The first thing I have to say about this beer is that its surprisingly good. I didnt expect much from a Ohioan lambic, but my curiosity got the better of me and I am glad that it did. The  aroma is very potent with distinct sourness like balsamic and white vinegar. There are hints of oak, muscadine and a sharp bitterness like hops. The flavor is not super refined and nuanced like some of the finest authentic lambics, but this is quite tasty, assertive and well balanced. There are plenty of suggestions of goat cheese, hay, oak, muscadine. Its a crisp and flavor brew.
Sampled at GABF on Saturday October 13, first sessionHazy golden color, white head. Funky, acidic, tart scent. Sweet, tart, acidic, fruity taste. Medium thin mouthfeel, lo wbitterness.

Courtesy of Matt. It pours sort of opaque grapefruit juice (Im taking this as a very good sign) with thin off white head. The aroma offers up spicy yeast mixing with sour sort of citrus notes and a rich vinegar. Cool. The aromatics really draw me in for a swig. The taste has a nice pucker of acidity and then it moves toward some vinegar. It dries out into the finish. Nice stuff.

750ml bottle from Dutchs Bar & Bottle Shop in Cincinnati, OH. 2011 vintage. Pours a hazed, pale gold colored body with a finger-width, fizzy, white head that dissipates quickly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is pretty tart with acidic lemons, a moderate funk, and a light dry wood. Some apricots, apples, must, and yogurt. Flavor is similar. Tart up front with some lemons, apricots, and apples with a light acidity. Some funk in the middle with some white wine before a light wood helps completely dry this as it finishes very clean with a light wheat note and a slightly funky, lactic sourness. Medium length aftertaste following a light body and a moderately lively carbonation. Overall, a pretty solid beer. Tart and dry with a light funk, wood, and acidity. Very clean and easy drinking making this really enjoyable. Good lambic.

Thanks to the kind soul that shared this at the recent Tampa Tasting.  Pours a hazy yellow with a small white head.  Nose is vinous fruit, yeast, some vinegar, tartness, and some funk.  Flavor is similar with vinous qualities, some tart grapes, and vinegar.  Funk, too.  Interesting American lambic.  Very nice overall.

Courtesy of Jan (fonefan), vintage 2010Muddy pale blond color. Very nice aroma: tart, cobwebs, lemon. Lean and dry mouthfeel; lemony flavor, with mild wild character. Astringent mouthfeel, with a sour character.Really good.

Pours hazy gold no head. Aroma of vinegar, citrus and funk. Taste follows, really good lambic

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750 ml bottle into a brandy snifter

This is upon opening has some of that classic lambic smell, which is always a good thing. Once entering the glass it bubble up about 1/2 a finger of head before quickly disappearing into a very slim rim of bubbles. the nice golden hue of the beer is vibrant and cloudy at the same time. the aroma from the opening still last in the glass and is very enticing, which leads into the taste. the taste wasnt quite as stellar as the smell, it has a bit of watery essence at the end of the sip, that would be the biggest complaint. 1 or 2 yrs down the road i can see this developing more in the bottle. the mouthfeel was spot on for a nice american sour. overall im glad i have a second bottle and ill be seeking at least one more out. good job Rivertown, I cant wait to get my hands on the other sours from this "local" brewery.

Pours a clear golden color with a white head.  A light vinegar note, but still a decent lactic character.  Lots of lemon peel, straw, and a decent funkiness, though mostly just must.  A touch of oak and green apple.  The palate is a little dull, but not awful.  Good tartness with oak, green apple, lemon, and a touch of white vinegar.  Not terribly complex or funky, but still nice.

bottle. Pours hazy gold with white head. Aroma tart funky lemons, brett and
acido, Flavors acid tart lemons pinnapple sharp acidic finish, thin
body, good but not very drinkable.

22oz capped and corked, thanks skyview.  Cork was a bitch to get out as it broke in half and was falling apart already.  Clear bright straw yellow with decent bright bigger bubble head that settles down.  Bright lemon, chalky, acidic, some punky wood.  Enjoyable Midwest lambic

Funky ligjt lemon tart musty dusty nose hay a little cider. Poura yellow golden w haze no head or lace. Hay musty cider notes a little funk lemon and rubber. Decently put together. Well carbonated light body. Acidic funk at times, mildly tart at times.

750ml bottle (2011) - pours murky gold/pale orange with thin white head and thin lacing.  Nose is yeast and cork.  Flavor adds light fruitiness (berries) and some woodiness.  Sweet and lightly acidic.  The alcohol is well hidden (i thought it would be 3.8%).

Tasted on 12/26/11 from a 750mL bottle.  Pours hazy light orange with an average white head that slowly recedes to a thin collar of lace.  The nose is sour and funky with tons of lemon peel, light malt, and just a touch of oaky vanilla.  The flavor is more of the same, super sour, tart, and funky with tons of lemon peel, a touch of white wine vinegar, light malt, and a bit of vanilla.  The body is medium with average carbonation and a long sour lemon peel finish.

Bottle shared by bgburdman at Muckfest III - Pours yellow with a white ring of head. Nose is cheesy funk, a little lemon, and a bit of vinegar/Smarties tartness. Taste has some nice funk, with Smarties tartness, crisp with a lemony, dry apple bite. Very nice and refreshing. Snappy carbonation with a medium body. Excellent stuff.

Bottle shared at MuckFest 3 - Friday evening addition. 2010 Vintage. Pours a richly golden glowing hue, some straw edges and body. Firm haze, frothy offwhite carbonation dies to a nice small ring, laces ok. Aromas are richly fruity, banana and apple mix with lactic acid, yogurt and lemons, touches of bready malts, dough, cereal grains. Firm melon, touches of more lemon, crab apple, and some kisses of grapefruit, apricot, and lemons grow. Really nice nose. gentle white wine, fruity elements from the barrels really come through. Initial is lighter end of medium bodied, offering richer sour and tart fruit, lemons and crab apple, some pear, banana, creamy lactic yogurty quality comes into the fold. Touches of white wine, melon, gentle apricot. Lemons and lactic quality takes some good life into the backend and finish. Firm sourness lingers, doesnt overpowering, doesnt get acidic. A really quality sour, very underrated. Good lactic element, funk, some straw and cereal grains. Really good. We opened a 2011 right after and the 2010 was several notches about. Very good.
Thanks puddintane! Lemon zest nose with oats. Murky grey gold, small white head. Mild, mellow, doughy on the edges, tart middle. Very clean finish.

750ml bottle caped and corked, 2010 vintage, poured a light orange color, aromas of dry apple cider with a touch of barnyard yeast.  Flavors are same, first sip was horseblanket mixed with apples, wasnt too excited abouut it.  Second si was much better, dry apple cidar, with light apricot, and a touch of sice, with some light funk and vineagar.  Great lambic after the first sip.
2011 Vintage. Pours a hazy orange color with a small white head.  Aroma of apple, tart, yeast, and wood. Flavor is sweet and tart, very cider-like.  Extremely easy to drink. Very enjoyable.

Bottle at James place.Pours hazy gold with a white head. Earthy and woody, with lighter lemony citric sweetness, floral undertones, and a nice gentle acidic tartness. I had never even heard of this brewery before, but damn this is some good shit.

Bottle shared with the hombrew crew. Pours a cloudy orange color with a small white head. A nice dusty and fruity nose. The flavor is vanilla, oak, rich tartness, funky, a bit of apple and lemon. Quite good. Mellow.

Med gold, cloudy, white head. Flavor:  pilsner malt, cherry-like tartness, moderate acidity, some wood evident. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
750 ml bottle thanks to Doug. Lemon, dusty, horse blanket, and citrus. A nice lambic. A bit thin, bright acidity, very complex.

Bottle courtesy of Andy at a tasting at James place.  Pours a hazy gold with a  thin white head.  Fuzzy musk and popcorn sweetness, caramel, light funky acid.  Medium bodied, sweet acid and funky.  Vibrant acid with lovely effervescence.  Bright and tight, funky acid and musk.  Very nice.  Beautiful.
Pours a very hazy golden yellow with a decent-sized white head.  Nose is cider and green apple.  Flavor is the same with plenty of puckering sourness.  A really nice lambic from my hometown!
Great funky noise, bright golden color, awesome apple undertones, and bright citrus notes all around a great lambic. highly recommend picking some up if you get a chance.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2012 2010 vintage.  Bottle to oversized snifter.  Looks good; light-orange with lots of CO2 that fades into thin lacing.  Smells pretnice; like a real lambic.  Tastes good too; not distinguished, but very drinkable, and a great fruit-free lambic for beginners.  Mouthfeel is good.  Easily my favorite brew from Rivertown, and one that Ill come back to, especially for the price.

Bottle 750ml.[ Courtesy of Secret Summer Santa ]. Hazy matt medium yellow colour with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy yeasty, tart, wood, barnyard - manure notes, light leather. Initial flavour is moderate to light light heavy sweet and light acidic, finish flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet with a average duration, dry dry, tart, tart citrus - grape. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is flat. [20120323]

This was a big treat for me- incredibly sour, and even more surprising incredibly malty. Lots of thick sweet fresh bread flavor, followed by a great stinging, puckering tartness. Sometimes gueuzes or lambics leave me wanting some more flavor, something other than just sourness, and this one really delivers. Sampled at the second annual East Nashville Beer Festival.

A hazed blonde lambic with a thin white head. In aroma, classic epsom salts, sour cherries, light acetic points. In mouth, a nice salty epsom salt with fruity acidity, nice and smooth, light horseblanket. Tasted with the Bartowel crew at Pushkinwows, March 23, 2012.

Bomber, sampled at the 2nd Ottawa tasting (although I like Karls description better). Cloudy yellow with a slightly off white head. A nice mellow sourness, grass, dry, some lemon and orange peel. Moderate carbonation, somewhat thin especially on the finish, herbs, a bit dry. Overall a mellow and mild lambic.

Sample at pushkinwows Beer Geek Extravaganza. 24MR12. 
App.:  Milky bright yellow with a small white head.
  
Aroma:  Typical horse blanket, rubber, funk, bitter herbs, peppery, Lambic.
  
Palate:  Medium body, soft effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Lemony, little funky, spicy, approachable; sour and refreshing.

Mild and and affable.
Bottle @ AA-Meeting, Western Denmark 2012. Pours hazy dark golden with a white head and lacings. Manuer and brett. A bit of funk. Quite some grapes. Refreshing and pleasantly acidic. Quenching.

750ml from Puddintane - thanks, Dave! What a nice treat for FFL payouts! Lovely, brimming, lustrously carbonated pour and a pale orange, moderately sedimental body. Huge dry white wine nose with just a bit of funk and dry hops. Herbal and tart but with a lightness and an elegance that was surprising to me. Crisp as hell in the finish. Dry and refreshing but with a pleasing complexity overall. Very nice surprise.

bottle shared by Brigadier, Thanks we all oggled over the award winning ohio lambic, but then we poured the thin, fizzy yellow barely flavored drink we were all taken aback.. this one gets high marks from me only because it was so bland it couldnt offend me.

650 ml bottle

The bottle says "award winning" but I cant figure out what competition this may have been victorious at. As a beer it isnt all that bad. As a lambic it falls completely short of expectations. Ive had berliner weisses with more sourness.

Aroma / Appearance - Strike one is the huge cascade of gushing foam that not only wasted the top few ounces but sucked all the yeast residue into the body. Instead of a clear orange what was poured into peoples glasses was a cloudy orange. White wine, vinegar, sweat socks, and lemon rinds are spot on for a lambic ... yet it still feels lacking. Maybe it is the overall mildness.

Flavor / Palate - Sour lemons, citrus, vinegar, and cheap white wine blend into a smooth easy to drink experience. The finish is a bit dry but lacks the true sourness that came from a Cantillon someone opened next. I would probably have finished the bottle if this were my choice for the night but neither do I regret the fact that about a third was left at the end of the tasting.

Sampled at the DC Local Tasting pours a basically opaque, grapefruit pulp yellow with some wispy white head.  Nose is nice, perfume, hay, light funk.  Flavor is nice, lemons, funk, a little band aid.  Medium bodied, tart finish.  Tastes like watered down Cantillon.
Bottle. Pours hazy yellow with thin white head; spare lacing. Aroma is light sour fruit, coriander, and light yeast. Flavor matches the nose. Light body and warmth with medium carbonation.
Bottle.  Murky yellow color, large white head.  Aroma of peach and lemons.  Taste is slightly sour lemonade.
Sour with some vinegar. Cloudy with no head. Sour wit a hint of vinegar and some lemon rind in the finish.

Sampled at a recent RB St. Louis gathering - Pours hazy yellow with a small white head.  The aroma is very tart with citrus and vinegar traits.  There is also a bugginess to it along with barnyard and lemons.  Medium / light crisp body with semi-sharp carbonation.  The flavor starts out with clean sharp citrus sourness.  However, malt shows through here more than any lambic Ive had before which gives it a smoothness.  The finish has some vinegar notes and sharp fruit.  Nice US version of a lambic.

Bottle thanks to soboleg. Pours a cloudy earthy gold with an off-white head that lasts throughout the beer. Aroma has scream nice funk note with some sour fruits and a bit of backing sweetness. Flavor has funk (barnyard) with a bit of sourness that melds with a sweet fruit finish.

Bottle from deyholla.  Thanks Derek!   Pours a cloudy yellow with a nice white head.  Nose is lenony leather with a nice veil of horse blanket.  Flavor is a slightly lemony wood horse blanket with a nice musty finish.  Subtle hay and honey in the finish.  Lingering and tingly on the tongue.  Great beer; nice surprise.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: 750 ml bottle from Dutchs. Shared at the STL RB Gathering. 2010 vintage, the first bottling. Pours a semi-cloudy straw gold color with a medium bone white head. Aroma of tart lemon juice, white grapes, yogurt, herbs, and oak. Flavor follows suit exactly, but the tart, sour, bright notes really come through more. Light-medium bodied, with a dry, tart mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Crisp finish. Really nice, and very surprising. Whether this is a true unblended lambic or not, I salute Rivertowns ambition and really dug this.

Sampled at the Saint Louis Ratebeer Gathering into tulip glass. Thanks, phaleslu for sharing a rare American Unblended Lambic, my last remaining style. Woo-hoo! Poured a hazy, light yellow color with strong lasting white head, some Belgian lace. Powerful lambic aromas: fruity, sour and tart, but not nearly as barnyard or horse-blanket as I expected, perhaps because its still (relatively) young. Mild but complex wheat-based farmhouse grainbill. Reminiscent of Berliner Weiss. Effervescent, metallic Champagne-like mouthfeel. Crisp snap at finish. Really tasty. Way to go, Ohio!

Sampled at the St. Louis RB gathering.  It poured a hazey straw yellow color with a minimal head. The aroma was of tartness, musty and an earthy tone. The flavor was the same as the aroma with a somewhat sour finish.

Sampled at the st. Louis ratebeer gathering.  Very hazy dingy gold.  Sour and nice yeast in the nose.  Spice and fruit.  The flavor is tart citrus with yeast.  This is tasty.  An interesting beer and my last untasted beer style.

Courtesy of Styles
Bottle:  The aroma consists of musty, oaky, and sour lemon.  It pours a molly dull orangish-lemon with a moderate white head.  The flavor starts with sour lemon and citrus.  The finish has some light oak and more sour lemon.  Its ligjt-medium bodied with mild carbonation.  Overall, very refeshing and sour.  I will say the milky appearance leaves a little to be desired.  Im surprised this doesnt score higher.
Light golden, hazy, minimal head. Musty, cheesy, lacto, light lemon sourness. Musty basement, light lemon sourness, lacto. Could use some more carbonation but other than that pretty solid.

Bottle. Ok, first time trying this style and tried to be fair but just dont care for it. Aroma was extremely funky. Taste like cider vinegar, mixed with malt and hops, sour. Cloudy with bits of stuff floating in it.

Bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy dark gold body with a nice frothy white head that had some decent retention.  The nose is fairly restrained, just a bit of funk, a little woodiness, some light wild cider like qualities.  The flavor is a little acetic and lacking in depth, just a little sourness on the back end.  The funkiness just doesnt seem to be expressed enough.  The mouthfeel is fairly dry, but it could be drier.  Light fizzy carbonation.  All in all, it seems like they may be on the right track with this beer, but if they want to get serious about making lambics, it takes time to get the right flora going.
Really an awesome unblended lambic from a random brewery here. Really excellent lemon, grain, and restrained but perfectly present funk. Clean, really good beer.
Murky yellowish pour. Aroma is cheesy, sour, woody, yeasty. Flavor is sour, fruity, white wine, yeasty. Awesome.

From the bottle at GABF. Pours  nice looking hazy gold with a head that dissipates. Nose is funky. Barnyard, pie cherry, Lactic acid and pure funk. Really decent nose. On taste, really solid. Dry white wine, yogurt and lemon juice. Some barnyard funk and the cherries make another appearance. Nice deep acidity that is clean. No vinegar. Really nice American sour.

750ml bottle, vintage 2010, thanks to Ryan011235.  Gusher alert!  Really cloudy yellow in color with a head that fades quickly.  The aroma is actually like a real lambic - not bad!  Funky and lemony and oaky aroma with a slight floral note.  Decent flavor, not at all bad, just not as complex as a legitimate lambic.  Dry, vinous, lemony, funky, with some oak.  Decent sourness.  Medium-bodied with medium acidity and fairly prickly carbonation.  Not half bad for a random-ass Ohio "lambic."  Next to a Cantillon though (and I tried this), no contest.

Bottle from Belmont Party Supply shared with the DC crew. Gusher. Pours a hazy straw color with a fizzy white head. Decent head retention. Very tart aroma with notes of citrus, must, vegetal notes and sweet fruit notes. The taste is tart citrus, caramel and earthy notes. Medium bodied.
Bottle. My first unblended lambic so dont think Im speaking from much experience here. 1 finger head. Straw color. Light, tart and refreshing. Very nice and easy drinking.
murky lemon, white ring. Dusty, lightly sweet. Heavy lemon and grapefruit rind, light cobweb. Flavor is dry, thin citrus, lasting grapefruit. No malt, no acid, very tame for an unblended.
Oraque peachy orange pour with a vanishing white head. Lactic acid, nectar fruits, and dry cheesecloth, sporting a medium palate with high carbonation levels, and caressing silky effervescence.

Bottle shared by dkachur: pours a cloudy pale golden with a spotty-lacing white head.  Has a lightly floral and funky nose with some horseblanket notes.  Starts with decent fullness and effervescent carbonation with a lightly puckering tartness.  Pretty true to style and drinkable.

Sweet grapefruit nose with some decent funk and a touch of hay/cobwebs.Taste is lightly sweet, lightly sour, some funk, some citrus, rather thin with dull malts. Wish they hadnt used crappy American 2-row as the base malt...

750mL thanks to dkachur. Pours a hazy yellow peach with a small white head. Nose is intense apricot, peach, pretty intense funky white wine. Very intense and funky. Taste is big carbonation up front, mild peach and apricot. Overall mild with nice spritziness. Good stuff. Nothing that I would say is like lambic unblended. Nose is a bit detergent heavy. Thinner, tart, stone fruit heavy. Not bad.

Bottle shared by dkachur.  Pours hazy gold with a light, fizzy white head, no retention or lacing.  Aroma is black walnut, light straw and hay malt, fruity esters, grape and vinous.  Flavor is lactic acid, vinous and grape notes, sour with light bitterness, light fruity esters and a dry finish.  Medium body, low warmth and heavy carbonation.

750ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy peachy golden color with a small to medium off-white head.  The aroma has a moderate tart/acidic quality with lactic notes and citrus.  There are definite oak barrel notes.  The flavor is moderately acidic, somewhat musty, woody and dry.  Some mild vinous notes.  This is a somewhat unexpected solid offering from an up and coming local brewery.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2012 bottle conditioned 750ml, 2010 release. hazed dull gold body with a small off-white head.  nose is moderately tart/acidic with sour cream lacto notes and mild oak barrel presence (port wine barrels, apparently, but without any port character evident, thankfully).  firm and rigid body with tight, natural carbonation.  balance of acid, must / yeast, oak and raw wheat character is surprisingly good, and overall the softness and delicateness of the bacteria is remarkably old-world and belgium-like.  lengthy, drying, prickly and acidic finish.   was told directly by the brewer this was spontaneously fermented by resident yeast/bacteria in the air around the brewery when I would have guessed inoculation, but perhaps Cincinnati has some decent bacteria concentrations.

This is a golden color with a white head. The aroma contains some vinegar, lemons, some barnyard thing. The is somewhat sour with lemons and vinegar. Call this one Lambic Lite! Overall this was pretty good and it might be the best thing to come out of Cincinnati since WKRP.

...because when I think lambic, I think...Cincinnati? Well, no, and I dont know how much of a "true" lambic this is. but this was a tasty brew, possibly the surprise of the tasting. Lemony sour, lightly herbal, and some vinegar notes. solid and tasty.

Sample at a tasting at Suttrees. Pours hazy yellow with some floaties and some white head. The aroma is musty and subtle with some lemon an even a wheat note. Taste is very subdued with light funk and some wheat and malt notes. Pretty good, really, but something along the lines of a table lambic.

Bomber, vintage 2010.  Nose of very sour and lightly funky metal.  Top-shelf Sour nose!  Cloudy light yellow, loud sudsy white head.  Taste is puckeringly sour, extreme tang with lots of lactic and minimal balsamic.  Good lemon up front, wheat throughout.  Other than the pucker, the medium body ends up being smooth and crisp, with a soft lactic feel.  Dry with a mild lacto/bready aftertaste.  I will henceforth be an unabashed supporter of this one, its got some character and a ton of drinkability.  Impressed.

Pours a hazy orange-gold color with a medium white head that recedes steadily. Top ring of lacing with spots underneath. Citrus, brett and malt in the nose. Medium body with a moderately tart fruit character and that has some funk behind it. Notes of grapefruit, malt, peaches and yeast. The finish is fruity with tart citrus left behind along with some sweet yeast. Above average overall.

Bottle via alexsdad06 in the Summer Secret Santa, thanks again! Pours a golden hazzy color with fizzy white head.  Aroma is slightly sour but doesnt really stand out much.  Some white wine notes.  Flavor is a crisp green apple, little to no funk and again white wine with a low to moderate sourness.  Overall it was a nice sour but rather middle of the road and safe.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Cloudy hay golden color with a nice white head.  Aroma is tart, light must, funk, lovely horse blanket, fruit.  Flavor is sour and funky with fruits, acidic, lemon zest.  Very nice sour coming out of the Queen City.

22 ounce bottle from Jungle Jims. Bottle cap with cork underneath. Cork broke in half while unscrewing. Pulled out second half safely. Aroma is white wine. Then a nice lambic aroma follows. Orange zest. Tart apple. Lemon. Tartness. Very dry lambic. But the citrus stands out. It pushes the dryness of the lambic into a bit of sweetness as well. This is nice and I should have bought two bottles instead of one.

2010 bottle via a trade. Pours with a hazy golden body with a small white head. Aroma of lactic acid, wheat, funk, fruity, musty, cobwebs. Flavors are sour, light funk, a noticeable acetic presence, medium to high lactic acid. Lively carbonation, dry finish. Decent.

(750ml bottles)  Pours a cloudy maize body with a small fizzy white head.  Aroma of lemon, grapefruit, bread,  blue cheese, and horse blanket.  Flavor of grapefruit, lemon peel, meringue, lacto, brett, white grapes, minerals, and subtle apple.
22oz bottle @RBSG shared by bu11seye-pours a disappearing white head and cloudy yellow color.  Aroma is tart, wheat.  Taste is tart lemon/spice hops, brett, wheat/light malt.

Bottle at Stone Sour Ale Fest 2011.  Straw yellow with slight haze and white head.  Grain, brett funk, lemon, peach, sweetness, yeast, and some light oak.  I nice sour ale, I would like to try it again.
75cl bottle, RBSG grand tasting.  Small white head, cloudy lemon yellow body.  Aroma is medium sweet, lemon/funk.  Taste is medium sweet, lemon, bread, some funk.  Light-medium body, some acidity.

Rivertown lambic. 750ml bottle. thanks to bgbrian.. Pours a hazy peachy pale pour with a  
lighlty soapy white head.... Pours a pale golden murky pour... Aroma  
of semifunky mild grapefruit funky like arOma... Flavors are much of  
the same. Very much sour and quenching in that aspect . Enjoyable  
to a high degree and a very pleasant surprise.  wasnt expecting much from this offering and would gladly try more.
7/4/8/4/14
Bottle. Poured a cloudy yellow color with an averaged sized white head. Funky aromas of fruitiness, yeast, and citrus. Tastes of citrus, fruity, funky, and bretty.

Bottle courtesy of alexsdad06.  Pours hazy amber with a thin white head.  Smells tarte, acidic, dry with some rosey hints and residual sugar persence.  Tastes minerally and lactic tarte initially with some dry peachy hints and a floral finish.  Very drinkable.

Very relaxed and mellow. The malt still shines in this lambic. Notes of light white sugar and soft malt. Lighter acidity than expected. Only complaint is the massive amount of yeast that stirs so easily. If you dont pour this entire beer all at once it is just yeastville to the extreme. Very delicious. Oh, be careful with that cork...

750 ml capped and corked bottle, 2010 vintage.  Served in a flute, the beer pours a hazy straw gold color with about a half inch white head.  Head retention is decent, and theres a small amount of lacing.  Aroma is lemon peel, oak, and some funk.  Its a nice but light aroma.  The brew tastes like tart apples, pears, lemon peel, vinegar, and some funk.  Nice lingering tart finish.  Mouthfeel/body is light/medium and its well carbonated.  I think this is a good brew, Id buy this again in the future.  Definitely worth a try.
UPDATED: JUN 26, 2012 Bottle at RBSG. Pours gold. White head. Nose/taste of Brett, tart citrus fruits, apricot, yeast and moderate tartness. Medium body.
22 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is fruity and dry citric hoppy. Fruity and citric. Bitter and fruity. Citric and lingering dry fruity into the finish.
Orange pour with white head and lace. Aroma is bretty and Belgian yeast.  Flavor is sour malt, yeast, and bread. A bit thin and fizzy. But not bad

When I heard about this beer I thought it had to have been a mistake by the brewery that they tried to market as a lambic. Although all the rivertown beers I have tried have all been very good, none of them were very bold. This beer is a legit american style sour ale. It had a very nice acidic nose and flavor. It was very drinkable for the style and probably the biggest surprise I have had this year.

Reviewing this beer as an American Wild, not as a traditional lambic, as it would not stack up nearly as well when compared against Cantillon, 3F, etc.

Thanks to Eric for opening this bottle. Served in a Bruery tulip.

Pours a light straw-yellow color with a mild white head. The nose brings some light cheese and funk with a bit of acidity. The taste starts like a berliner with some mild grain and wheat plus a touch of acidity. Some mild peach and apricot character there. Light body and mild tartness with low carbonation. The nose brings some bready yeast as it warms. Mild acid in the finish. A really nice attempt and a solidly-drinkable brew, especially on a pretty warm evening.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-13-2011

Bottle at Troys.  2010. Hazy straw yellow with minimal head.  Tart, musty, dirty blanket, earthy aroma.  Great level of sour in this one.  Puckering but not over powering.  Grainy, straw flavors with apple cider and perhaps a light yeasty presence.  Very nice.  Quenching, light body.  Id drink this any time.  Finally!  Cinncinatti makes something good!

Bottle sampled at the 2nd Annual Sour Town tasting on 4/23/11. Hazy and chunky yellow pour with a thin white head. Nose is sour lemon, a bit of sweet malt and vinegar. Sour lemon flavor a bit of maltiness and a sour vinegar finish thats rather thin. Way better than I was expecting from a brewery Ive never heard of, but could use some work on the body.

Bottle corked. Poured hazy orange color with an average frothy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy sour yeast aroma. Medium body with a dry tingly texture and soft carbonation. Medium sour cider flavor with a medium sour finish of moderate duration. This is a very good for style beer.
750 ml bottle, Pours hazy orange gold w foamy towering head, aroma is pleasant pithy sourness, flavor is smooth and crisp wih a great snappy sour finish, tasty and refreshing, very impressed
